instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2012

There is no picture (even on external screen) and no chime, but CPU and GPU warms up. It beeps without RAM, but that's the only sign of life. Will not start in SMC bypass mode, or after SMC reset - I've never seen it running. I tried to flash the BIOS chip with known good one (with clean ME) for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, but nothing changed (so I flashed back the old one). There were no signs of spills, oxidation or previous repairs. It looks to me like dead CPU? I've got one CPU for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> on stock, so I can change it, but I'm not sure if it's really dead when it still beeps without RAM... Also why would it die? The chip itself looks OK, like everything else on the motherboard.


<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.11V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL> 0.90V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.53V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.33V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.05V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 5.05V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.04V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> 1.50V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL> 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.03V
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> 0.74V

<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0.00V
<SIGNAL>DP_MUX_EN</SIGNAL> 1.00V
<SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 1.02V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.10V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.09V

<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL> present

Thank you

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message: Beeping without RAM means it is at least sort of alive. Is a USB mouse lighting up? PRAM reset with external keyboard done with everything else disconnected?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message: No, USB mouse is not lighting up, I tried both USB ports and 5V is there, but no light.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message:
Beeping with no RAM when using another BIOS too? Tried RAM in just 1 slot at a time?
Any other history as to how this happened?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message:
Sorry, I did not remember history of this board when I wrote the first post. It came to me about a year ago with no <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>, because <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_UGATE</SIGNAL> was shorted through <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. After changing <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> the <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> came back, but that's all. 

It beeps even with different BIOS, I tried one downloaded BIOS for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and one from a known working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board - still the same. Without RAM it's just one long beep that repeats after a few seconds. 

I tried all possible configurations of RAM and about 4 different tested working pairs with different frequencies (12800, 10600, L, non-L...), but it's always the same - with any RAM in any slot it's quiet, without RAM it beeps.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message: Ah, so there was an issue on CPU Vcore. I'm pretty sure the CPU was damaged when that happened :( RIP.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Brain dead... or zombie at least
threads.message: Yes, you are right, I changed the CPU and I did not fully test it yet, but it boots now :) So this one is solved, thanks
